awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Description: The development of materials capable of targeted therapy and diagnosis or "theranosis" allows for simultaneously interfacing and treating diseased cells while visualizing what is happening through imaging. Powerful computational and experimental tools will be employed to develop magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)-traceable protein fibers capable of delivering drugs. The resulting biomaterials will have broad societal impact in the field of drug delivery and tissue engineering. Lessons learned from these studies can be employed for delivery of other chemical agents with applications extending to non-medical industries including personal care, cosmetics and environmental remediation. This research will train the next generation of scientists and engineers to employ cutting edge technologies in computational biology, protein engineering and materials science to create, rapidly screen and characterize new functional biomaterials. The project will also engage girls (predominantly women of color) from the Urban Assembly Institute for Math and Science for Young Women who are traditionally underrepresented in STEM on biomaterials in alignment with the Next Generation Science Standards. In collaboration with the start-ups, InSchoolApps, and the MakerSpace, the girls will participate in biomaterials chemistry, computer programming, rendering of proteins in three dimensions and visualization.

Technical description: The fabrication of multifunctional materials that can self-assemble into defined structures bears tremendous potential for a number of application including drug delivery and tissue engineering. One challenge is to deliver an appropriate chemical agent and non-invasively monitor the surrounding area amidst a complex biological milieu or extracellular matrix (ECM). The ECM is comprised of protein fibers (from the nano to microscale) organized into a mesoscopic three-dimensional network. The development of a material capable of targeted therapy and diagnosis or "theranosis" would enable one to simultaneously interface with specific cells while providing both detailed functional and molecular information through visualization. We intend to drive design of protein fibers through computation and assess through experimental analysis, their physicochemical properties with the objective to predictably: 1) control self-assembly into fibers on the mesoscale with functional capabilities of small molecule recognition; 2) integrate non-canonical amino acids that encode thermostability and traceability using our developed algorithms for fluorinated amino acids, beyond the limits of biological diversity; and 3) biomineralize and order iron oxide nanoparticles on the organized protein fiber substrates leading to image-ready bio-nanocomposites with magnetic properties. The intellectual merit of this proposal relies on developing a new paradigm for coiled-coil protein materials design that cycles between computation and experimentation. This will enable the rapid iteration for controlling fiber assembly and the identification of rules for coiled-coil fiber and nanocomposite design. In addition to employing state-of-the-art open source programs, we will also use synthetic biology to produce the proteins enabling synthesis for high-throughput screening. This work is well aligned with the Materials Genome Initiative, as we will apply the computational tools already built for protein design with the aim of fabricating novel biomaterials, in this case fibers and inorganic-organic hybrid composites. The versatility of the proposed materials will not only prove useful for applications in biomedicine, but also will lead to fundamental insight into computational methods for modeling and designing protein fibers and nanocomposites.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The investigation into supramolecular assembling coiled-coils has yielded new protein sequences capable of either fiber formation, hydrogel formation, or both as well as garnered computational workflows allowing for the design and prediction of other protein sequences with similar capabilities. These findings are fundamental to the thermostability and electrostatic interactions of these proteins which shows promise in translation to other fields studying nanomaterial interaction, specifically protein-protein interactions (PPIs).

In particular, we have shown that hydrogel gelation kinetics is proportionally dependent on fiber diameter, and furthermore, can be predicted completely in silico using publicly available software, Rosetta and PDB2PQR-APBS. Among the characterization of these nanomaterials, we have implemented and shown the utility of our high-throughput microrheological assay towards characterizing gelation kinetics in a library of hydrogel forming coiled-coil proteins, which may be used across in time-dependent gelation systems.

In development of our prediction models, we have furthermore selected our fastest gelling hydrogel for structural assessment through collaboration with Brookhaven National Laboratory and the University of Delaware to collect small angle x-ray scattering (SAXS) and cryo-EM to assess the time-dependent structural changes of coiled-coils. In doing so, we have confirmed the predominantly longitudinal nature of protofibril assembly which will be critical as criteria for future design of not only coiled-coil proteins, but other fibrous self-assemblies.

Also characteristic of our fastest gelling coiled-coil hydrogel variant is its low pI, which we predicted to have an improved chance of hydrogel formation at low pHs. A large fraction of shampoos and skin creams are formulated at or below pH 6 which has signaled this variant for investigation as a potential protein-based rheological modifier. In collaboration with DOW, we have shown that our hydrogel is indeed capable of hydrogel formation at low pH (pH 6) whereas our original variant was not.

Finally, we have explored coiled-coil fibers for potential as theranostic agents by bioconjugation of iron-oxide nanoparticles for T2*-darkening via noncanonical amino acid incorporation (NCAA) of azidohomoalanine and via NCAA incorporation of TFL for 19F MRS traceability. We have shown that a leucine-dense variant is capable of a high density of noncanonical amino acid incorporation (NCAA) of trifluoroleucine. Importantly, we show that fluorination impacts the fiber diameter and thus lateral assembly of fibers, a critical parameter in the design of supramolecular assembling hydrogels. Furthermore, we show that using a high concentration of fluorinated fibers, we are able to create contrast in 1H MRI by T2-shortening, an imaging characteristic that will be useful in visualization and traceability of supramolecular assembly biomaterials. Finally, we also show that fluorination of a coiled-coil provides sensitive and unique 19F MRS traceability of coiled-coils strengthened by their fibrous morphology which leads to a dense, localized 19F signal.

 

 


Last Modified: 05/23/2023
Modified by: Jin K Montclare
por.por_txt_cntn:
The investigation into supramolecular assembling coiled-coils has yielded new protein sequences capable of either fiber formation, hydrogel formation, or both as well as garnered computational workflows allowing for the design and prediction of other protein sequences with similar capabilities. These findings are fundamental to the thermostability and electrostatic interactions of these proteins which shows promise in translation to other fields studying nanomaterial interaction, specifically protein-protein interactions (PPIs).

Among the characterization of these nanomaterials, we have implemented and shown the utility of our high-throughput microrheological assay towards characterizing gelation kinetics in a library of hydrogel forming coiled-coil proteins, which may be used across in time-dependent gelation systems.
